articles.title: Law Puts Us All in Same Danger as Eric Garner - Bloomberg
articles.snippet: Dec 4, 2014 ... Husak cites estimates that more than 70 percent of American adults have committed a crime that could lead to imprisonment. He quotes theÂ ...
articles.summary:
On the opening day of law school, I always counsel my first-year students never to support a law they are not willing to kill to enforce.
Usually they greet this advice with something between skepticism and puzzlement, until I remind them that the police go armed to enforce the will of the state, and if you resist, they might kill you.
I wish this caution were only theoretical.
Whatever your view on the refusal of a New York City grand jury to indict the police officer whose chokehold apparently led to the death of Eric Garner, itâ€™s useful to remember the crime that Garner is alleged to have committed: He was selling individual cigarettes, or loosies, in violation of New York law.

People ask me all the time: Hey, Marc Lopezâ€”why are you always telling people to plead the 5th?
I think itâ€™s because I truly believe in my heart that itâ€™s objectively better to be safe than to be sorry.
Plead the 5th.
Safe is better than sorry, which is why I tell anyone who will listen to always plead the 5th.

Harvey Silverglate, a civil liberties attorney, titled his 2009 book â€œThree Felonies a Dayâ€ to indicate how easily we can fall afoul of the United Statesâ€™ metastasizing body of criminal laws.

But fewer laws would mean fewer opportunities for official violence to get out of hand.
A just society should have very few laws, and those laws should be both easy to understand and they should focus on protecting life, liberty, and property.
